questions.question: What is Android?
questions.details: Android is a stack of software for mobile devices which includes an Operating System, middleware and some key applications. The application executes within its own process and its own instance of Dalvik Virtual Machine.
questions.shortAns: A stack of software for mobile devices.

questions.question: What is a Service?
questions.details: Android service is a component that is used to perform operations on the background such as playing music, handle network transactions, interacting content providers etc.

questions.question: What is the APK format?
questions.details: The Android packaging key is compressed with classes, UI's, supportive assets and manifest. All files are compressed to a single file that is called the APK.
questions.shortAns: It is compressed with classes, UI's, supportive assets and manifest.

questions.question: What is an intent?
questions.shortAns: It is a declaration to do something.

questions.question: What is an android manifest file?
questions.details: Every application must have an AndroidManifest.xml file (with precisely that name) in its root directory. The manifest file presents essential information about your app to the Android system, information the system must have before it can run any of the app's code.
questions.shortAns: It is a resource file which contains all the details needed by the android system about the application.

questions.question: What is AAPT?
questions.details: AAPT is short for Android Asset Packaging Tool. This tool provides developers with the ability to deal with zip-compatible archives, which includes creating, extracting as well as viewing its contents. This tool allows you to view, create, and update Zip-compatible archives (zip, jar, apk). It can also compile resources into binary assets.
questions.shortAns: It is a packaging tool and is included in the tools directory of the SDK.

questions.question: What is an activity?
questions.details: Activities are what you refer to as the window to a user interface. Just as you create windows in order to display output or to ask for an input in the form of dialog boxes, activities play the same role, though it may not always be in the form of a user interface.
questions.shortAns: It is the window to a user interface.

questions.question: What is an Intent?
questions.details: Intents displays notification messages to the user from within the Android enabled device. It can be used to alert the user of a particular state that occurred. Users can be made to respond to intents.
questions.shortAns: it displays a notification message to the user from within the Android enabled device.

questions.question: What is a container?
questions.details: Containers, as the name itself implies, holds objects and widgets together, depending on which specific items are needed and in what particular arrangement that is wanted. Containers may hold labels, fields, buttons, or even child containers, as examples.
questions.shortAns: It holds objects and widgets together.

questions.question: What is Orientation?
questions.details: Orientation, which can be set using setOrientation(), dictates if the LinearLayout is represented as a row or as a column. Values are set as either HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL. As with almost all smartphones, Android supports two screen orientations: portrait and landscape. When the screen orientation of an Android device is changed, the current activity being displayed is destroyed and re-created automatically to redraw its content in the new orientation
questions.shortAns: It dictates if the LinearLayout is represented as a row or as a column.

questions.question: What is adb?
questions.details: Adb is short for Android Debug Bridge. It allows developers the power to execute remote shell commands. Its basic function is to allow and control communication towards and from the emulator port.
questions.shortAns: It allows developers the power to execute remote shell commands.

questions.question: What is an intent filter?
questions.details: Because every component needs to indicate which intents they can respond to, intent filters are used to filter out intents that these components are willing to receive. One or more intent filters are possible, depending on the services and activities that is going to make use of it.
questions.shortAns: It specifies the types of intents to which an activity, service, or broadcast receiver can respond to.

questions.question: What is an intent filter?
questions.details: An intent filter specifies the types of intents to which an activity, service, or broadcast receiver can respond to by declaring the capabilities of a component. Android components register intent filters either statically in the AndroidManifest. xml or in case of a broadcast receiver also dynamically via code.
questions.shortAns: It declares the capabilities of its parent component.
